member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.ConstraintSolver.ValueConstraint.Reference
member.summary: When true, the value constraint is not considered while solving the system and the constraint value is allowed to change. When false (default), the constraint behaves normally maintaining the specified value and influencing the solving process. Setting this field to true may be useful for measuring lengths, distances, angles, etc.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.ConstraintSolver.Sketch.AddConstraintJoin(devDept.Geometry.ConstraintSolver.ISketchCurve[])
member.summary: Joins the given list of sketch curves to create an open contour. Constraints are created by trying to minimize the distance between each endpoint and the following. Curve directions do not influence the outcome, which is only dependent on point distance.Please note that this method does not close the contour (the user should add an additional constraint if needed).
member.param: A list of curves to be joined together. The first curve will be the start of the path and joined with all the others by starting from one of the endpoints: for this reason, passing as the first entity a curve that is in the middle of the path would produce unexpected results.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.ConstraintSolver.Sketch.AddConstraintJoin(devDept.Geometry.ConstraintSolver.ISketchCurve,devDept.Geometry.ConstraintSolver.ISketchCurve)
member.summary: Joins the two given curves creating a points coincident constraint for the couple of closest endpoints.

member.summary: Adds a mirror constraint between two entities
member.remarks: The two entities must be of the same type.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Utility.GetLinesTangentToTwoCircles(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle)
member.summary: Computes the segments tangent to two given circles or arcs.
member.returns: The array of lines tangent to both circles. For arcs, it returns only the lines that touch them.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Utility.GetLinesTangentToTwoCircles(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Line[]@)
member.summary: Computes the segments tangent to two given circles.
member.param: Array of length 4 containing the tangent lines.
member.returns: The number of not null lines in .
member.remarks:
For arcs, it returns the same result as for circles, for a different result use . All the lines start from c1 and end on c2, except for the tangent lines that are perpendicular to the gLine connecting the two centers, we will refer to these tangents as vertical or VERT: their length is equal to the diameter of the bigger circle and they touch the circles at the midPoint. The position of the lines in the array is fixed and dependent from the number of solutions:
[0] upper external (or outer),
[1] lower external (or outer),
[2] upper internal (or inner),
[3] lower internal (or inner). To define upper we use the positive direction of the Y axis of the plane with axis Z equal to c1.Plane, and axis X given by the direction c1.Center-c2.Center. Based on the number of solutions, the possibilities are:
0 => [null, null, null, null]: one circle is completely inside the other and they don't intersect,
1 => [null, null, null, VERT]: one circle is completely inside the other and they are tangent
2 => [LINE, LINE, null, null]: the circles intersect in two different points, there are only the external tangents,
3 => [LINE, LINE, VERT, null]: the circles intersect in one point, but they aren't one inside the other, there are the external tangents and a vertical tangent,
4 => [LINE, LINE, LINE, LINE]: the circles don't intersect and they aren't one inside the other, there are the external tangents and the internal tangents.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Utility.GetCirclesTangentToTwoCircles(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Computes the circles tangent to two given circles or arcs.
member.param: The radius of the tangent circles
If true, it trims the tangent circle at the tangent points.
It is significant only when trim is true. If false (default) it returns the shortest part of the tangent circle, if true it returns the longest part.
member.returns: The array of circles tangent to both circles. For arcs, it returns only the circles that touch them. The StartPoint of the output circles lie always on c1. If trim is true, the trimmed arc goes from c1 to c2.

member.summary: Computes the tangent lines from a point to a circle.

Array containing the not-null tangent lines.
member.remarks: For arcs, it returns only the lines that touch them. The tangent lines are directed from the point toward the circle.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Utility.GetLinesTangentToCircleFromPoint(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Circle,devDept.Geometry.Point3D)

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Utility.CheckDataIntegrity(System.String@,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.String}}}@)
member.summary:
Checks the data integrity between the Workspace controls.
It compares item-by-item all the master collections of all the Workspace instances, searching for objects used in more than one Workspace.
member.param: The log file containing details about shared items.

The dictionary containing the shared items.
Listed below are the element types you can find in it
- Layer: items that belong to the collection.
- Block: items that belong to the collection.
- Material: items that belong to the collection.
- TextStyle: items that belong to the collection.
- LineType: items that belong to the collection.
- HatchPattern: items that belong to the collection.
- Entity: items that belong to the collection.
- BlockEntity: items that belong to the collection.
- BlockEntity+Entity: items that belong both to the and to the collections.
member.returns: True when no instances are shared between different Workspace controls, otherwise false.
member.remarks: You can't share objects (i.e. , , , etc.) between different Workspace controls, but you need to clone them before adding to another Workspace control. If you get wrong display results or artifacts, you can use this method to check out shared elements.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.SurfaceMesher.DoSmoothing(System.ComponentModel.BackgroundWorker,System.ComponentModel.DoWorkEventArgs)
member.summary:
Smooth the mesh, moving the vertices in order to minimize the difference between each edge length and the element size. During the smoothing process, the following operations are performed (in this order):
1. For each edge: flip it if it can get closer to the element size.
2. For each vertex: move it in order to improve the connected edges, and remove it if necessary.
3. For each edge: collapse it (remove it) if it can improve the lengths of the connected edges.
The process is repeated number of times.

summary.para: A generic abstract class for meshing.

member.name: T:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.VolumeMesher
member.summary: Unstructured tetrahedral mesher class definition. Generates tetrahedron meshes on 3D domains defined by boundary triangle meshes and possibly some embedded nodes, edges and faces.

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.VolumeMesher.TargetMetric
member.summary: Element size inside the domain. The elements size tends toward this value as they get away from the hard (boundary) edges. Discarded when <= zero.
member.remarks: This parameter is often used to reduce the total number of elements (when target metric > default sizes based on boundary edge lengths) and to save FEM computation time without loosing much on element shape quality. The target metric may be smaller or bigger than the default sizes based on boundary edge lengths.

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.VolumeMesher.MaxGradation
member.summary: This parameter controls the gradation of the elements size from the boundary sizes to the size defined by inside the domain. A value close to zero leads to a more progressive variation of mesh size (smoother). Discarded when <= zero.

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.VolumeMesher.OptimizationLevel
member.summary: Optimization level between 0 and 10. Controls the trade-off between speed (low values) and high element quality (high values). The higher the level, the more aggressive the algorithms.
member.remarks: The algorithms involved here aim at optimizing both the shape quality of the elements and their size quality (length of elements' edges). Hence, increasing the value of may lead sometimes to a reduction in the shape qualities (min, average or max value) whereas the global quality (which takes into account both types of quality) gets better. The parameter controls the weight of the shape quality in the global quality measure. Level zero disables any optimization.

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.VolumeMesher.ShapeQualityWeight

summary.para: Weight on shape qualities versus size qualities. Scalar between 0 and 1 indicating the importance of the shape qualities versus the size quality for the regularization step:

item.description: For values greater than 0.5, the shape quality is privileged.
For values lesser than 0.5, the size quality is privileged.

member.remarks: Default = 0.6 (slight preference for shape quality). Should not normally be changed.

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.Meshing.VolumeMesher.Statistics.SteinerNodes
member.summary: Gets the number of final steiner nodes.
member.remarks: In 2D, it is possible to triangulate any domain using only the nodes of the boundary mesh and respecting all the constraints. This is not true in 3D. Internal nodes, called Steiner nodes, are sometimes needed in order to produce valid tetrahedrons. These Steiner nodes are inserted during the constraints enforcement phase(front mesh).

member.name: T:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector
member.summary: Represent a circular sector centered in the origin. A circular sector is the portion of a disk enclosed by two radial vectors. This class considers the disk to have an infinite radius, therefore one sector represents an infinite portion of plane.

member.summary: Sector start vector (counter-clockwise).

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector.End
member.summary: Sector end vector (counter-clockwise).

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector.CentralAngle
member.summary: Central angle of the sector (varying in 0-2PI).

member.name: P:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector.Domain
member.summary: Domain (start and end angles) of the sector.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector.Contains(devDept.Geometry.Vector2D)
member.summary: Check if the specified vector is inside the circular sector.
member.returns: True if the vector is inside the circular sector, false otherwise.
member.remarks: It is not required to normalize the given vector.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector.#ctor(devDept.Geometry.Vector2D,devDept.Geometry.Vector2D)
member.summary: Standard constructor, to be used when the counter-clockwise arrangement of the enclosing vectors is known.
member.remarks: It is not required to normalize the given vectors.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.CircularSector.#ctor(devDept.Geometry.Vector2D,devDept.Geometry.Vector2D,devDept.Geometry.Vector2D)
member.summary: Standard constructor, providing a vector parameter to specify which of the two possible circular sectors enclosed by the vectors is to be chosen.
member.param: Vector contained in the desired sector
member.remarks: It is not required to normalize the given vectors.

member.name: T:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock
member.summary: Represent a plane subdivision in four quadrants, based on two vector axes. This class may be used to obtain the angle range of each section and to retrieve the quadrant where a point lies.

member.name: F:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.MainAxis
member.summary: Main axis, used to define the clock orientation.

member.name: F:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.SecAxis
member.summary: Secondary axis, used to define quadrants.

member.name: F:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.SwappedAxis
member.summary:
When true, the angle between the main axis and the secondary axis is greater than 180 degrees.
+----> Example of swapped axis. The secondary axis is | pointing downwards with respect to the main | axis: the angle is 270 degrees. v

member.name: F:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.StartAngle
member.summary: Angle of the main axis (varying in 0-2PI).

member.name: F:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.QAngle
member.summary: Quadrant angle: angle between the main and the secondary axis, varying in 0-PI.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.#ctor(devDept.Geometry.Vector2D,devDept.Geometry.Vector2D)
member.summary: Create a vector clock based on the given axes.
member.remarks: It is not required to normalize the given vectors.

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.Quadrant(devDept.Geometry.Point2D)
member.summary:
Retrieve the number of the quadrant where the given point is located. Quadrants are numbered from 0 to 3. The point is evaluated relative to the origin: if axes are (1, 0) and (0, 1), the point (1, 1) is in quadrant 0.
1 | 0 ---+---> 2 | 3
Please note that the numbering starts from and proceeds counter-clockwise (as shown above, where the main axis corresponds to the x-axis).

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.VectorClock.Locate(devDept.Geometry.Point2D,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Retrieve the quadrant where the given point is located.
member.returns: An interval with the quadrant start and end angles.

member.name: T:devDept.Geometry.Transformation
member.summary: 4x4 transformation matrix.
member.example:
Usage example.
Transformation t = new Translation(10, 0, 0); Transformation r = new Rotation(Math.PI/6, Vector3D.AxisY); // angle in radians
Transformation c = t * r; // combines the two transformations (order matters)
Point3D pt = new (10, 20, 30);
Point3D newPt = c * p; // transforms the point pt
Dim t As Transformation = New Translation(10, 0, 0) Dim r As Transformation = New Rotation(Math.PI/6, Vector3D.AxisY) ' angle in radians
Dim c As Transformation = t * r ' combines the two transformations (order matters)
Dim pt As Point3D = New (10, 20, 30)
Dim ptNew As Point3D = c * p ' transforms the point pt

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Transformation.Rotation(devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Point3D)
member.summary: Creates a new transformation of rotation.

summary.para: Creates a new transformation of rotation.

The frames should be right hand orthonormal frames (unit vectors with Z = X X Y). The resulting rotation fixes the origin (0,0,0), maps initial X to final X, initial Y to final Y, and initial Z to final Z.
Creates a new transformation of rotation.

The frames should be right hand orthonormal frames (unit vectors with Z = X X Y). The resulting rotation fixes the origin (0,0,0), maps initial X to final X, initial Y to final Y, and initial Z to final Z.

If the initial and final center are equal, then that center point is the fixed point of the rotation. If the initial and final point differ, then the resulting transform is the composition of a rotation fixing P0 and translation from P0 to P1. The resulting transformation maps P0 to P1, P0+X0 to P1+X1, ...
Creates a new transformation of rotation.

The frames should be right hand orthonormal frames (unit vectors with Z = X X Y). The resulting rotation fixes the origin (0,0,0), maps initial X to final X, initial Y to final Y, and initial Z to final Z.

If the initial and final center are equal, then that center point is the fixed point of the rotation. If the initial and final point differ, then the resulting transform is the composition of a rotation fixing P0 and translation from P0 to P1. The resulting transformation maps P0 to P1, P0+X0 to P1+X1, ...

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Transformation.ChangeBasis(devDept.Geometry.Plane,devDept.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Computes a change of basis transformation.

remarks.para: If you have points defined with respect to planes, the version of ChangeBasis() that takes two planes computes the transformation to change coordinates from one plane to another. The predefined world plane Plane.XY can be used as an argument.
If P = plane0.Evaluate(a0, b0, c0)
and (a1,b1,c1) = ChangeBasis(plane0, plane1) * new Point3D(a0, b0, c0)
then P = plane1.Evaluate(a1, b1, c1)
The version of ChangeBasis() that takes six vectors maps (a0, b0, c0) to (a1, b1, c1) where a0*X0 + b0*Y0 + c0*Z0 = a1*X1 + b1*Y1 + c1*Z1.
The version of ChangeBasis() that takes six vectors with center points maps (a0, b0, c0) to (a1, b1, c1) where P0 + a0*X0 + b0*Y0 + c0*Z0 = P1 + a1*X1 + b1*Y1 + c1*Z1.
The change of basis transformation is not the same as the rotation transformation that rotates one orthonormal frame to another. See the Rotation() method.

member.returns: True if the operation succeeded, false otherwise

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Transformation.ChangeBasis(devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D)
member.summary: Computes a change of basis transformation.
member.returns: True if the operation succeeded, false otherwise

member.name: M:devDept.Geometry.Transformation.ChangeBasis(devDept.Geometry.Point3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Point3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D)
member.summary: Computes a change of basis transformation.
member.remarks: Change of basis transformations and rotation transformations are often confused. This is a change of basis transformation. If Q = P0 + a0*X0 + b0*Y0 + c0*Z0 = P1 + a1*X1 + b1*Y1 + c1*Z1 then this transform will map the point (a0,b0,c0) to (a1,b1,c1)
member.returns: True if the operation succeeded, false otherwise.

member.name: P:devDept.Serialization.Surrogate`1.Version
member.summary: Gets the Eyeshot proprietary file format version used for this surrogate.
member.remarks: Internally set with the file header's version.
It's set before reading and before writing the surrogate, so it can be used as a discriminant in methods , when reading and when writing.
It is equal to -1 when not initialized yet.

member.name: F:devDept.Serialization.Surrogate`1.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets the file header tag (for deserialization purpose only).
member.remarks: It can be used to handle custom versions. It is filled by the method with the data get from the file header.

member.summary: Gets the list of errors and warnings generated during the serialization/deserialization processes.

member.summary: Creates the object related to the surrogate when reading data.

member.name: M:devDept.Serialization.Surrogate`1.CopyDataToObject(`0)
member.summary: Copies common data from surrogate to object when reading data.
member.remarks: This method is called by method after the creation of the object instance.

member.name: M:devDept.Serialization.Surrogate`1.CopyDataFromObject(`0)
member.summary: Copies all data from the object to its surrogate when writing data.
member.remarks: Use this method to fill ALL the properties of this surrogate. It is called by the empty constructor to initialize the surrogates properties.

After calling this method both and methods will be skipped of course.

member.summary: The serialization type for the Eyeshot proprietary file format.

member.name: F:devDept.Serialization.fileType.Standard
member.summary: A standard Eyeshot file containing all data.
member.remarks: Standard file is also generated when using class for "leaf" sub-assemblies.

member.name: F:devDept.Serialization.fileType.Assembly
member.summary: An Eyeshot file containing assembly info.
member.remarks: Usually, this file contains BlockReference entities and paths for related blocks. Anyway, it can contain also other types of entities if present at the root level of the assembly itself.

member.summary: Writes a protocol-buffer representation of the given object to the supplied stream with a length-prefix.
member.param: The tag used as a prefix to each record.
member.remarks: You can use this method to write an object as protocol-buffer representation. You had to store the FileHeader somewhere to guarantee the backward compatibility when reading. The opening and the closing of the stream is delegated to you.

member.name: M:devDept.Serialization.FileSerializer.DeserializeWithLengthPrefix``1(System.IO.Stream,System.Int64@,System.Boolean@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Applies a protocol-buffer stream to an existing instance (or null), using length-prefixed data.
member.param: The binary stream to apply to the instance (cannot be null/Nothing)
Returns the number of bytes consumed by this operation (includes length-prefix overheads and any skipped data).
True when an object has been read, otherwise false.
The tag used as a prefix to each record.
member.returns: The updated instance; this may be different to the instance argument if either the original instance was null, or the stream defines a known sub-type of the original instance.
member.remarks: You can use this method to read an object from a protocol-buffer stream representation. You had to serialize the file header before using this method to guarantee the backward compatibility when reading. The opening and the closing of the stream is delegated to you.

remarks.para: Use this method to fill ALL the properties of this surrogate. It is called by the empty constructor to initialize the surrogates properties.
Beware, when this method is called, both and fields are not initialized yet.

members.member:

Use this method to add check/warning messages to the .

member.name: M:devDept.Serialization.LabelSurrogate.CopyDataFromObject(devDept.Eyeshot.Labels.Label)
member.summary: Copies all data from the object to its surrogate when writing data.

remarks.para: Use this method to fill ALL the properties of this surrogate. It is called by the empty constructor to initialize the surrogates properties.
Beware, when this method is called, both and fields are not initialized yet.

members.member:
Integrity check according to the .
Use this method to add check/warning messages to the .
During the serialization process, it is called internally before serializing the surrogate.
During the deserialization process, you can use it for your custom surrogate checks in or in methods in conjunction with the .
. . . . . . .

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.IViewportUI.SmallSizeRatio

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid during dynamic movements (Zoom/Pan/Rotate). Default value is 0.01. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.IViewportUI.SmallSizeRatioMoving

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid during dynamic movements (Zoom/Pan/Rotate). Default value is 0.01. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.IViewportUI.SmallSizeRatioStill

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid on the still frames. Default value is 0. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Viewport.SmallSizeRatio

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid during dynamic movements (Zoom/Pan/Rotate). Default value is 0.01. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Viewport.SmallSizeRatioMoving

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid during dynamic movements (Zoom/Pan/Rotate). Default value is 0.01. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Viewport.SmallSizeRatioStill

summary.para: Gets or sets the ratio to classify small entities. Small entities are hid on the still frames. Default value is 0. Use zero to disable.
This ratio is used by to estimate value in pixels.

member.remarks: The on screen object size is calculated approximating the size of the object's bounding box. Most of the times, there is a big difference between the actual pixel footprint and the value.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Region.QuickOffset(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Quick offset function for NC toolpaths.
member.returns: An array of curves, offset of the region contour list.
member.remarks: Despite the type of the ICurves creating the contours of the region, it will return only Arc and Lines, occasionally organized into CompositeCurves. Sharp corners are not preserved. It doesn't work if the contours of the region intersect.

member.summary: Pocket function for NC toolpaths.
member.returns: An array of curves, pocket of the region.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Mesh

summary.para: A triangle mesh is a type of polygon mesh in computer graphics. It comprises a set of triangles (typically in three dimensions) that are connected by their common edges or corners.
Depending on the types of vertices and triangles, it can assume different configurations, see table below.

item.description: Plain1
MulticolorPlain
Smooth1
MulticolorSmooth
ColorPlain
ColorSmooth
RichPlain
RichSmooth

summary.para: 1 Allows transparency to be used

member.summary: Fillets two coplanar curves with an arc of given radius.

When true the second curve is trimmed
member.returns: True if the operation is successful, false if the curves don't lie on the same plane or don't touch.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Curve.Fillet(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve,devDept.Geometry.Vector3D,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Arc@)
member.summary: Fillets two coplanar curves with an arc of given radius.
member.param: Unit vector, normal to the plane on which both curves lie.
When true the first curve is trimmed
When true the second curve is trimmed
member.returns: True if the operation is successful, false if the curves don't lie on the same plane or don't touch.
member.remarks: Looking at the curves from the top of planeNormal placed at the intersection, the fillet will be on the left side of a curve if its flip parameter is false, and on the right side if its flip is true. Use planeNormal only if you know exactly how the curves are oriented and where you want the fillet to be placed. Otherwise, set it to null or call the Fillet() method without planeNormal and we will compute it internally.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.knotVectorType.PiecewiseBezier
member.summary: Another common knot vector format is for piecewise Bézier igCurves. These are usually used when a bunch of simple primitives, such as arcs, lines or simple curve segments are strung together into a single large curve. Again, if k is the order, then the curve passes through each k’th point on the curve, and passes near all of the others. In other words, the curve is broken into segments of k points each. Moving any control point within a particular segment affects only that segment, and moving a point where two segments join affects both. If the joint and the control points on either side of it are in a straight line, then the two segments form a smooth continuous curve.3 Otherwise a sharp “kink” or discontinuity occurs. Example: {0,0,0, 1,1, 2,2, 3,3,3}

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Solid.Intersection``1(``0,``0,System.Double)

summary.para: Boolean Intersection between two solids. The method will compute the intersection between the two specified solids (gray and blue in the image below) and return an array with the result (green). The returned array may have more than one element if multiple disjoint intersections are found.

member.param: Optional tolerance, start with domain size * 1e-6
member.returns: An array of solids if the operation is successful. If the operation is successful but no intersections are found, an empty array is returned. Otherwise, if due to an error the algorithm fails to compute the intersections, null/Nothing is returned.

summary.para: BRep solid entity definition. A manifold solid B-rep is a finite, arcwise connected volume bounded by one or more gSurfaces, each of which is a connected, oriented, finite, closed 2-manifold. There is no restriction on the genus of the volume, nor on the number of voids within the volume.

The Boundary Representation (B-rep) of a manifold solid utilizes a graph of edges and vertices embedded in a connected, oriented, finite, closed two manifold gSurface. The embedded graph divides the gSurface into arcwise connected areas known as faces. The edges and vertices, therefore, form the boundaries of the face and the domain of a face does not include its boundaries. The embedded graph may be disconnected and may be a pseudo graph. The graph is labeled; that is, each entity in the graph has a unique identity. The geometric gSurface definition used to specify the geometry of a face shall be 2-manifold embeddable in the plane within the domain of the face. In other words, it shall be connected, oriented, finite, non-self-intersecting, and of gSurface genus 0.

Faces do not intersect except along their boundaries. Each edge along the boundary of a face is shared by at most one other face in the assemblage. The assemblage of edges in the B-rep do not intersect except at their boundaries (i.e., vertices). The geometry curve definition used to specify the geometry of an edge shall be arcwise connected and shall not self intersect or overlap within the domain of the edge. The geometry of an edge shall be consistent with the geometry of the faces of which it forms a partial bound. The geometry used to define a vertex shall be consistent with the geometry of the faces and edges of which it forms a partial bound.
A B-rep is represented by one or more closed shells which shall be disjoint. One shell, the outer, shall completely enclose all the other shells and no other shell may enclose a shell.

member.summary: Creates a Brep from skinning.
member.param: If True, it splits the igCurves at corner points. It is useful when the sections are Composite Curves with similar shape, and you want to line up the corners (and curve segments) in the resulting Brep.
if true, it creates a closed Brep
Works only when splitAtCorners is true. If true, when the tangents have the same direction but different lengths, the curve will be split. If false, it won't be split.
the regeneration tolerance. 0 for default value
member.returns: The resulting Brep if the operation succeeds, null/Nothing otherwise.

The disjoint contours (lying on the selected face) to be used to split the face.

The usage of SubdivideBy is suggested at the end of the model construction, for example to perform FEM analysis.

member.summary: The Brep silhouettes drawing type.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep.silhouettesDrawingType.Standard
member.summary: Draws the silhouettes on all faces.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep.silhouettesDrawingType.SkipPlanars
member.summary: Avoids processing planar faces. Suitable for transparent objects.
member.remarks: The silhouettes are drawn with the same thickness as the edges.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep.silhouettesDrawingType.SkipInwardPrimitives
member.summary: Avoids processing all planar faces and primitive faces of revolution (Cylindrical, Conical, Spherical, Toroidal) with set as false (like cylindrical holes). Suitable for opaque objects.
member.remarks: The silhouettes are drawn with the same thickness as the edges.

member.summary: Gets or sets the silhouettes drawing mode.

member.param: The Brep entity equivalent to the original with additional data. The original one if the operation failed.
member.remarks: The original brep is modified when the operation is successful.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep.MergeAndKeepFaces(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep,devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep,devDept.Eyeshot.MaterialKeyedCollection)
member.summary: Merges two Brep objects preserving only one copy of duplicated face.

remarks.para: Original objects must not intersect and faces must be compatible (equal and opposite).
You may need to call on original objects to rebuild parametric faces.
Will fail (not yet supported), when an object is completely inside the other and is not null/Nothing.

member.param: The materials collection. When defined, the resulting Brep faces colors will conserve the input objects colors.
member.returns: A single Brep with only one copy of -internal- duplicated faces when successful. Null/Nothing otherwise.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep.MergeAndKeepFaces(System.Collections.Generic.IList{devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Brep},devDept.Eyeshot.MaterialKeyedCollection)
member.summary: Merges a list of Brep objects preserving only one copy of duplicated face.

remarks.para: Original objects must not intersect and faces must be compatible (equal and opposite).
You may need to call on original objects to rebuild parametric faces.
Will fail (not yet supported), when an object is completely inside the other and is not null/Nothing.

member.param: The list of Breps objects to merge
The materials collection. When defined, the resulting Brep faces colors will conserve the input objects colors.
member.returns: A single Breps, with only one copy of -internal- duplicated faces when successfully merged. Null/Nothing otherwise.

member.summary: Creates a surface from skinning. The skinning is performed in the U direction.
member.param: The degree in the U direction

If True, it splits the curves at corner points. It is useful when the sections are Composite Curves with similar shape, and you want to line up the corners (and curve segments) in the resulting surface.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Surface.Loft(System.Collections.Generic.IList{devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.ICurve},System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a surface from skinning.
member.param: If True, it splits the curves at corner points. It is useful when the curves have similar shapes, and you want to line up the corners in the resulting surface.
Works only when splitAtCorners is true. If true, when the tangents have the same direction but different lengths, the curve will be split. If false, it won't be split.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FastMesh.ColorArray
member.summary: Gets or sets the color array, can be null/Nothing.

remarks.para: The size of the array determines how the colors are applied to the entity:

item.description: 1 byte per vertex is applied as a modulation factor (0-255) to the of the entity. This requires the use of shaders so the graphics acceleration must be turned on, must be true (WinForms control only) and the must be
3 bytes per vertex are applied as RGB colors
4 bytes per vertex are applied as RGBA colors (in order for the alpha transparency to work, the entity must also have a with alpha < 255 and must be set to false).

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FastPointCloud.ColorArray
member.summary: Gets or sets the color array.
member.remarks: The size of the array determines how the colors are applied to the entity: 1 byte per vertex is applied as a modulation factor (0-255) to the of the entity. This requires the use of shaders so the graphics acceleration must be turned on, must be true (Winforms Eyeshot control only) and the must be 3 bytes per vertex are applied as RGB colors 4 bytes per vertex are applied as RGBA colors (in order for the alpha transparency to work, the entity must also have a with alpha < 255 and must be set to false).

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FastPointCloud.ZoomFitSpeed
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of points skipped during zoom fit and bounding box computation.

remarks.para: This value indicates how often a point is chosen. In practice, we take one, discard 'n' and then take another, and so on.
Set to 0 for accurate ZoomFit and bounding box, increase for better performance.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.OrdinateDim
member.summary:
Ordinate dimension entity.
The ordinate dimension consists of an X or Y value with a leader line.
It measures the perpendicular distance from an origin point (called the datum) to a defining point (such as a hole in a part).
X-datum ordinate dimensions measure the distance of the defining point from the datum along the X axis.
Y-datum ordinate dimensions measure the distance of the defining point from the datum along the Y axis.
If the dimension is vertical it measures the X value. Otherwise, it measures the Y value.
member.remarks: Text font can be changed using the property and calling the Workspace.Entities.Regen() method.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.OrdinateDim.#ctor(devDept.Geometry.Plane,devDept.Geometry.Point3D,devDept.Geometry.Point3D,System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Standard constructor.
member.param: The dimension plane. Its origin is used to measure the distance from the defining point.
The type of the ordinate dimension (horizontal or vertical). If true, the x-coordinate is measured, otherwise the y-coordinate is measured.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.OrdinateDim.#ctor(devDept.Geometry.Plane,devDept.Geometry.Point2D,devDept.Geometry.Point2D,System.Boolean,System.Double)

member.param: The type of the ordinate dimension (horizontal or vertical). If true, the x-coordinate is measured, otherwise the y-coordinate is measured.

member.summary: Indicates if the ordinate dimension is vertical (when true) or horizontal (when false).

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FemMesh.ComputeGravity
member.summary: Computes an array whose values represent the distributed gravity force on each object in .
member.remarks: Standard gravity acceleration, i.e. (0 m/s², 0 m/s², -9.806650 m/s²), is used. Every element is considered to be linearly interpolated, even if that is not the case.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FemMesh.ComputeGravity(devDept.Geometry.Vector3D)
member.summary: Computes an array whose values represent the distributed gravity force on each object in .
member.remarks: Every element is considered to be linearly interpolated, even if that is not the case.
member.param: Gravitational acceleration vector. Must be dimensionally consistent with the other quantities in play.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FemMesh.SetGravity
member.summary: Estimates a gravity load for each vertex in the fem mesh, then it loads each unrestrained node.
member.remarks: Standard gravity acceleration, i.e. (0 m/s², 0 m/s², -9.806650 m/s²), is used. Every element is considered to be linearly interpolated, even if that is not the case.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.FemMesh.SetGravity(devDept.Geometry.Vector3D)
member.summary: Estimates a gravity load for each vertex in the fem mesh, then it loads each unrestrained node.
member.remarks: Every element is considered to be linearly interpolated, even if that is not the case.
member.param: Gravitational acceleration vector. Must be dimensionally consistent with the other quantities in play.

member.remarks: The setter resets the property as well.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Picture.FullPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the full path of the Picture's image for export purpose. Default value is null/Nothing.
member.remarks: This property is used when saving a file in DWG/DXF file format for skipping the automatic creation of the image on disk. By design, the Picture's image is stored in the same directory of the output file. This property is reset when property is set.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Picture.AnisotropicFiltering
member.summary: When true, enables anisotropic filtering for mipmapping.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Picture.MinifyingFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture minifying function. The texture minifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area greater than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.Picture.MagnifyingFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture magnifying function. The texture magnifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area smaller than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.BlockReference.MoveTo(devDept.Eyeshot.DrawParams)
member.summary: Allow the entity to be moved/rotated on the GPU using RenderContext calls during animation.

remarks.para: It is always recommended to call base class implementation from overriders.

It is important when applying an on-the-fly transformation in this method to override the BlockReference.IsInFrustum() and return true without calling the base method in order to avoid undesired clipping.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines if the is visible or not.
member.remarks: It does not affect the visibility of the but only of the . This allows to keep the Attribute visible when editing a (with ), so it can be selected and the property can be set to true or false without affecting its visibility on screen that would prevent to select it again. Then the will propagate the Invisible property to the AttributeReferences and make them invisible (after the current BlockReference is reset).

member.summary: Creates a block with the loaded entities, adds it to the , marks it as external reference and returns a BlockReference to that block.
member.param: The name of the block that will contain the loaded entities
Base point of the created BlockReference
The object to which add the block
The filename of the external reference. If empty, uses the name of the file read from disk or the ".dwg" if the file was read from a stream
The export mode that defines whether the file of the external reference will be written to disk in case of a subsequent call to . The ( export mode is not supported).
member.returns: The blockReference referring to the created block.

remarks.para: The block base point is taken from the .
The , , and are added to the and then are set to null.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.ReadDXF
member.summary:
Experimental helper class for loading DXF files. A list of supported entities follows.
Entity NameDetails
Point
Line
XLine
Arc
Circle
Ellipse
Text
MText
Leader
Polyline2D
Polyline3D
Spline
Face3D
PolyfaceMesh
PolygonMesh
Insert
AlignedDimension
OrdinateDimension
RadialDimension
DiametricDimension
Angular3PointDimension
Angular2LineDimension
LinearDimension
Solid
MLine
Hatch
Image
member.remarks:
Is supports file versions from Autodesk 2000 to Autodesk 2018.
Dynamic Blocks are not supported.
In case of unsupported files, refer to and use class.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.WriteMultiFileParams.UpdateThumbnails
member.summary: Indicates whether the thumbnail must be updated for all the written files or not. Default value is false and the thumbnail is stored only for the main file according to param.
member.remarks: When true and is true too, the thumbnail is updated for all files. This operation cannot be run in parallel and can increase a lot the working time for this work unit.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.WriteMultiFileParams.Parallel
member.summary: Indicates whether the writing of the files is performed in parallel or not (Default is True).
member.remarks: The updating of thumbnails is excluded from parallel process.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.ReadLAS.GetFastPointCloud(devDept.Eyeshot.Translators.ReadFastPointCloudBase.formatType)
member.summary: Gets the FastPointCloud read from the file.
member.param: The that must be used to create the resulting FastPointCloud.
member.returns: The FastPointCloud read from the file according to the .
member.remarks: If you need to get the FastPointCloud in a different format type than the one used in the constructor, please ensure to have set , and to true before reading the file.

members.member:
Gets the FastPointCloud read from the file as Block.
The that must be used to create the resulting FastPointCloud. The to use as insertion point for the creation of the related . The name of the block. If null/Nothing the name is assigned internally. The block containing the FastPointCloud read from the file.
Uses a block reference to avoid floating point precision problems. i.e. When files use the UTM 32 North projection with northing values > 5,000,000 and easting values > 435,000, the northing values are larger than the easting values and the limited precision of the floats leads to the points arranged in the lines. To get more accurated result, you can use double precision coordinates by setting to true before starting the reading process. If you need to get the FastPointCloud in a different format type than the one used in the constructor, please ensure to have set , and to true before reading the file.
.

summary.para: When true, entities at the same level of BlockReferences are encapsulated inside a new block.

Many CAD systems have difficulties to handle individual entities at the same level of BlockReferences. Using this flag, all individual entities at the same level of BlockReferences are replaced by a BlockReference with a name at random.

member.summary: Standard constructor.
member.param: The document containing collections for export purpose.
If true, only selected entities at root level are written.
The for the HTML body. It can be null/Nothing.
A string representing the HTML template for the output. It must contain both EyeshotGeometry and EyeshotScripts html comment tags to work properly.
member.remarks: The will add the bgcolor attribute but it may not work when you use a custom .
If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

example.code:
<html>
<script> ... <!-- EyeshotScripts --> ... </script> <body> ... <!-- EyeshotGeometry --> ... </body>
</html>

The for the HTML body. It can be null/Nothing.
A string representing the HTML template for the output. It must contain both EyeshotGeometry and EyeshotScripts html comment tags to work properly.
member.remarks: The will add the bgcolor attribute but it may not work when you use a custom .
If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

example.code:
<html>
<script> ... <!-- EyeshotScripts --> ... </script> <body> ... <!-- EyeshotGeometry --> ... </body>
</html>

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.BlockKeyedCollection`1.TakeOffline
member.summary: Temporarily suspends automatic regeneration and integrity checks on .

remarks.para: This method is useful for take the collection in an "offline" state and speed up the editing/reorganization. To resume the standard behaviour call .
Beware when the collection is "offline", it can lead to an inconsistent state and crash with methods like , , etc.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.EntityList.MaxCandidates
member.summary: Accurate transparency. This parameter affects transparency pre-processing and redrawing speed. Valid values are between 1 and the total number of semi-transparent triangles. The lower is this value the lower will be the time need for pre-processing, penalizing redrawing speed. Higher values normally improve the FPS rate.

member.summary: Accurate transparency. If true, skips back facing semi-tranparent triangles drawing, increasing the FPS rate.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.HatchPattern
member.summary: HatchPattern definition. The pattern is defined by a collection of HatchPatternLine. The process of hatching consists of expanding each line to its infinite family of parallel lines. member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Layer
member.summary: Layer definition. Layers are a way to group objects so that the groups can have common formatting. For example, you may want your objects to show up in one color and your dimensions to show in another. Create a separate layer for each, then you can change all the dimensions or all the objects at the same time. You may show or hide layers, change the color, lineweight, or linetype. Layers are utilized often to make drawing easier to read.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.LineType
member.summary: LineType class. The pattern defines pen-up lengths (spaces), pen-down lengths (dashes), and dots. A pattern specifies the length of segments that make up the linetype. A positive decimal number specifies a pen-down (dash) segment of that length. A negative decimal number specifies a pen-up (space) segment of that length. Zero specifies a dot. For example, the DASHDOT linetype is defined by a repeating pattern starting with a dash 0.5 drawing units long, a space 0.25 drawing units long, a dot, and another space 0.25 drawing units long.
member.remarks: When the line type used by entities already added to the is changed, their must be set to and the must be called.
Use an empty pattern for a continuous line.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.GetProjectionMatrix(System.Double,System.Double,devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.CameraEyePosType)
member.summary: Gets the projection matrix.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.SetupModelView(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.CameraEyePosType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gives a chance to derived classes to setup camera by two points and a vector.
member.param: When true, the scene transformation is applied as well.

example.code:
Public Class myCamera Inherits devDept.Eyeshot.Camera
Private myLocation As New Point3D(100, 0, 0) Private myTarget As Point3D = Point3D.Origin Private myUpVector As Vector3D = Vector3D.AxisZ
Protected Overrides Sub SetupModelView(setGraphics As Boolean, reflection As Boolean, cameraEyePos As Workspace.CameraEyePosType) modelViewMatrix = LookAt(myLocation, myTarget, myUpVector, reflection)
If setGraphics AndAlso renderContext IsNot Nothing Then renderContext.SetMatrices(projectionMatrix, modelViewMatrix) End If End Sub
End Class
Public Class Form1
Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
MyViewport.Camera = New MyCamera
End Sub
End Class

member.summary: Computes the intersection of the lines passing from the vertex and oriented like the frustum planes with the X and Y axes of the camera.

Angular coefficients of left and bottom frustum lines

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.NearPlaneDistanceFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the factor used to compute the near plane from the far plane distance.
member.remarks: By default it is 0.001 of the far plane distance. Set it to a smaller value if it's clipping too much geometry near the viewer in big scenes. Beware that too small values affect the scene rendering precision.
Call the and to see the effect of the change.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.WorldToScreen(devDept.Geometry.Point3D,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Maps world coordinates to screen mouse coordinates.
member.param: The 3D point to project on screen
member.returns: The associated projected screen point relative to the viewport (zero on bottom)
member.remarks: The z-component of the returned point is in the normalized device coordinate space [0,1]. A value outside the [0,1] range means that the point is outside the near-far clipping planes of the camera.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Camera.WorldToScreen(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32[])

member.remarks: The z-component of the returned point is in the normalized device coordinate space [0,1]. A value outside the [0,1] range means that the point is outside the near-far clipping planes of the camera.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Material.MinifyingFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture minifying function. The texture minifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area greater than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Material.MagnifyingFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture magnifying function. The texture magnifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area smaller than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Material.RepeatX
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture repeat mode in the X direction.
member.remarks: If true, values outside [0,1] are mapped to the [0,1] range. If false, values less than 0 are mapped to 0 and values greater than 1 are mapped to 1.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Material.RepeatY
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture repeat mode in the Y direction.
member.remarks: If true, values outside [0,1] are mapped to the [0,1] range. If false, values less than 0 are mapped to 0 and values greater than 1 are mapped to 1.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.SetCurrent(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.BlockReference,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a BlockReference as current.
member.param: The BlockReference to set as current
If true, updates the scene bounding box. Set it to false for better performances in off-screen methods that call this to just use the

remarks.para: If it is null, the current BlockReference is unset.
The BlockReference must be a first-level child of the one that is currently set (i.e. it must be in the entities of the ).
When a BlockReference is set as current, only the referenced block entities are active on the scene, others are still visible but in a "frozen" state.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.UpdateBoundingBox
member.summary: Computes the scene bounding box, rebuilds simplified representation and updates some important variables. If the bounding box, grid or shadow are visible, it updates them too.

remarks.para: Shadow is updated only if it is visible and if the design has the bounding box height bigger than zero.
It's important to call this method when the visibility status of some entities changes.
Visual refinement deviation is updated as well but you need to set as for all entities and call Workspace.Entities.Regen() method to see objects with new tessellation.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.GetVisualRefinementDeviation

member.remarks: Can be overridden to return a custom value.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.IsAntiAliasingAvailable
member.summary: Returns true if Full Screen Anti-Aliasing is available.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.ForceHardwareAcceleration
member.summary: Forces accelerated hardware modes. By default, Eyeshot automatically disables hardware acceleration on some embedded GPUs to obtain the maximum level of graphical output consistency between all hardware. In these cases, enabling this property will forcibly activate hardware acceleration, though the resulting graphics output may be unpredictable.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.IsBestAdapterAvailable
member.summary: Indicates whether the best adapter is available for the renderer initialization or not.

remarks.para: This value is written during the control's initialization, so it must be read after the control is correctly loaded.
This property is not valid when the is .

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.Entities
member.summary: Gets the EntityList of the . This collection contains the entities displayed in the viewport.
member.remarks: Never add a block definition to this collection. Add it to the blocks collection.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.TempEntities
member.summary: Temporary Entity collection. This collection contains the entities displayed in the viewport on top of the others as temporary entities.
member.remarks: Only IFace and ICurve types are supported into this collection. Each entity added to this list needs to the regenerated first.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.Blocks
member.summary: Block collection. This collection contains block definitions.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.RootBlock
member.summary: Gets the root block.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.RemoveJittering(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a block with the selected , computes the center of their bounding box, translates them all of the negative of that quantity and returns a BlockReference to that block.
member.param: The name of the block that will contain the selected entities.
member.returns: The blockReference referring to the created block.
member.remarks: When the entities are very far from the origin their appearance on screen may become very compromised, and the camera may shake badly when moving/rotating the view. To fix this issue you can select these entities and call this method.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.RemoveJittering(devDept.Eyeshot.Entities.BlockReference)
member.summary: Gets the blockreference entities, computes the center of their bounding box, translates them all of the negative of that quantity and translates the blockreference back to the original position.
member.param: The blockreference name of the block that will contain the selected entities.
member.remarks: When the entities are very far from the origin their appearance on screen may become very compromised, and the camera may shake badly when moving/rotating the view. To fix this issue you can select these entities and call this method.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.SaveScene(System.String)
member.summary: Saves the current scene on disk, including entities, textures, blocks and layouts.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.SaveScene(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Saves the current scene on disk, including entities, textures, blocks and layouts.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.
The closing of the stream is delegated to you.

summary.para: Restores the current scene from disk, including entities, textures, blocks and labels.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.

summary.para: Restores the current scene from disk, including entities, textures, blocks and labels.

remarks.para: This command can be very attractive to save and load models in you program but has a serious pitfall: it is based on standard .NET Serialization. This means that any change on the Eyeshot binaries (dll versions, dll names, type names, etc.) will invalidate all your existing files. We strongly recommend to use the Eyeshot proprietary file format or to implement your own file format (simply writing entities properties and recreating entities during file loading) if you need continuity between different Eyeshot DLL versions. Another option can be to use one of the standard format supported (DWG/DXF/IGES) where applicable.
The closing of the stream is delegated to you.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Workspace.AskForDirect3DLevel9_3
member.summary: If true, The Direct3D feature level 9_3 is requested during viewport initialization instead of the highest feature level available.
member.remarks: Used for compatibility problems with old cards.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase
member.summary: Base class for lead and ramp. Holds a set of points which can be rotated and translated to be tangent to a given stroke.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.Feed
member.summary: The feed rate for lead motions, i.e. the velocity at which the cutter is advanced against the workpiece. Please note that when this field is not valid (null), one tenth of the machining feed will be used by default. The feed specified in the array will in any case be overwritten.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.Motions
member.summary: List ot lead motions (see ). The shape of the lead (i.e., the path followed by the tool to approach the stroke) is defined by this list of motions. All motions in the list are considered as a chain, and they are added to the toolpath one after the other: therefore, the end point of one motions should be (approximately) equal to the start point of the following motion.

remarks.para: All motions are defined in the XY plane, where the origin corresponds to the lead point and the X-axis corresponds to the stroke tangent at the lead point. A lead-in or a ramp will therefore start from a generic point in the plane and end up in the origin, while a lead-out motion will start from the origin and end up somewhere else in the plane. For example, if we wanted to define a straight lead-in of length 10 that is always perpendicular to the stroke, we would use a linear motion that goes from (0, 10) to (0, 0). If we wanted a similar lead-out, we would do the same but swapping start and end points: from (0,0) to (0, 10).

When inheriting from , one should always set the list of motions. This can be done either in the constructor or in the method. Initializing the motions in the constructor will result in a static lead, that never changes shape: it is either a lead-in or a lead-out, or a ramp that always has the same height. On the contrary, initializing the motions in the method permits to change the lead based on the required parameters (e.g., lead-in or lead-out, ramp layer height).
Please note that the properties and of motions will be ignored and overwritten. To set these properties, please use LeadBase.Feed or Machining.Feed for the feed rate, Machining.Speed for the speed.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.InterPoints
member.summary: Points used internally to compute intersections between the lead and the strokes. An intelligent choice of can greatly reduce the computation time required to attach the leads to the strokes. In general: the less points the faster the process is, the more points the more precise the algorithm is in attaching the leads. In most cases, a lollipop approximation (that can be achieved by invoking ) is enough to obtain satisfactory results. When is an empty array, intersections are not computed and the lead can always be attached to the stroke.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.Init(System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes the lead. Child classes may override this method to initialize the array and/or the array.
member.param: Tolerance used to approximate the lead.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.LeadBase.BuildAsLollipop(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Approximate the lead as a lollipop, generating the intersection points using the specified radius and distance. A lollipop is a segment connected to a circle, which can be used to compute intersections more quickly. For example, a helix ramp can be approximated to a circle of the same radius. The lollipop circle is made up of 16 segments.
member.param: Distance from the contour to the lower point of the circle.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp
member.summary: Base class for ramp movements, vertical movements between Z levels, defining how the end mill should ramp into the stock. A ramp is a movement that the end mill has to perform while descending into the stock, before leading in and cutting the material. A ramp movement (if present) always comes before the cut, and never after.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.RadialClearance
member.summary: Not yet supported.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.ClearanceHeight
member.summary: The clearance height is the height reached by the tool with rapid movements. The ramp will be built ensuring that a distance in Z equal to the clearance height is kept between the start point of the ramp and the top of the remaining material.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Ramp standard constructor.
member.param: The height of ramp over the current stock level

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Ramp.Init(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Update the ramp based on the current cut direction and layer height (height of the material which has to be milled). The ramp will be updated by calling this method multiple times during the ramp addition process, after the toolpath has been computed. Child classes should override this method to update the array and (when needed) the InterPoints arrays based on the tolerance and the layer height.
member.param: Tolerance to build the ramp; see .
Height of the current level (part of the stock which has to be cut). The total height of the ramp should be equal to layerHeight + clearanceHeight.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.PlungeRamp
member.summary: Plunge ramp movement definition. A plunge ramp is a vertical straight movement which digs into the stock directly.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.PlungeRamp.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Standard constructor.
member.param: The height of ramp over the current stock level.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.HelixRamp
member.summary: Helix ramp movement definition. A helix ramp is a helical movement which digs into the stock gradually with circular motions.

member.summary: Standard constructor.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Lead
member.summary: Represents a lead (lead-in or lead-out), defining the movement of the tool as it approaches or leaves the stock. A lead-in is the motion of the tool before beginning a cutting move, while a lead-out is the motion of the tool as it ends the cut and leaves the material.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Lead.#ctor
member.summary: Standard constructor.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.Lead.Init(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Invoked internally during the lead adding process to update the lead. The Init method should be overridden by child classes to update and (when needed) arrays based on the tolerance and the lead type (lead-in or lead-out).
member.param: Tolerance to generate the lead, see .
True if the lead is a lead-in and will be used to approach the path, false if the lead is a lead-out and will serve to exit the path.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Milling.StraightLead

summary.para: Project class definition.

Project is a finishing strategy that allows you to machine along contours with the center of the tool. The provided contours are always projected onto the surface and therefore do not have to be on the surface. By default, the tip of the tool follows along the surface. The tool is moved into the surface by either entering an axial offset or a negative stock to leave.

summary.para: Parallel finish class definition.

Can be used either as a pre-finishing or a finishing operation. The cutter is restricted to follow the contours of the geometry in the Z direction while being locked to a series of parallel vertical planes.

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Simulation.DrawTranslationRestraint(devDept.Graphics.RenderContextBase)
member.summary: Gives the chance to overriders to customize translation restraint symbol drawing.

example.code:
Protected Overrides Sub DrawTranslationRestraint(ByVal context As RenderContextBase) ' one normal per triangle mesh Dim m As Mesh = Mesh.CreateBox(1, 2, 3); m.UpdateNormals() context.DrawPlainTriangles(m.Triangles, m.Vertices, m.Normals);
' or smooth normals mesh Dim m As Mesh = Mesh.CreateSphere(2, 16, 8) m.UpdateNormals() context.DrawTriangles(m.Vertices, m.Normals, m.Triangles, Nothing) End Sub

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Simulation.DrawRotationRestraint(devDept.Graphics.RenderContextBase)
member.summary: Gives the chance to overriders to customize rotation restraint symbol drawing.

example.code:
Protected Overrides Sub DrawRotationRestraint(ByVal context As RenderContextBase) ' one normal per triangle mesh Dim m As Mesh = Mesh.CreateBox(1, 2, 3); m.UpdateNormals() context.DrawPlainTriangles(m.Triangles, m.Vertices, m.Normals);
' or smooth normals mesh Dim m As Mesh = Mesh.CreateSphere(2, 16, 8) m.UpdateNormals() context.DrawTriangles(m.Vertices, m.Normals, m.Triangles, Nothing) End Sub

Protected Overrides Sub DrawLoadVector(ByVal context As RenderContextBase) ' one normal per triangle mesh Dim m As Mesh = Mesh.CreateBox(1, 2, 3); m.UpdateNormals() context.DrawPlainTriangles(m.Triangles, m.Vertices, m.Normals);
' or smooth normals mesh Dim m As Mesh = Mesh.CreateSphere(2, 16, 8) m.UpdateNormals() context.DrawTriangles(m.Vertices, m.Normals, m.Triangles, Nothing) End Sub

member.name: M:devDept.Eyeshot.Design.StartAnimation

summary.para: Starts the animation timer. After calling this method the Animate method of all the entities is called periodically to allow the computation of the new entity position.
To animate group of entities the approach is the following:

item.description: Create groups of moving objects (using class and adding entities to the collection)
Add blocks created at point 1) to the collection
Subclass the BlockReference class for each moving group of objects
Override the BlockReference.Animate() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to compute the data for entities transformation at that specific time frame
Override the BlockReference.MoveTo() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to move the objects on the GPU

Override the Entity.IsInFrustum() method of the class at point 3) and return true without calling the base to avoid undesired clipping. It might be necessary to override also the bounding box scene extents
Add the block references created at point 3) to the collection
Call StartAnimation() providing the time interval between each frame
Call StopAnimation() to stop the animation

member.remarks: During animation the silhouettes, if enabled, are skipped.

Add blocks created at point 1) to the collection
Subclass the BlockReference class for each moving group of objects
Override the BlockReference.Animate() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to compute the data for entities transformation at that specific time frame
Override the BlockReference.MoveTo() method of the class at point 3) and add the code to move the objects on the GPU

Override the BlockReference.IsInFrustum() method of the class at point 3) and return true without calling the base to avoid undesired clipping. It might be necessary to override also the bounding box scene extents
Add the block references created at point 3) to the collection
Call StartAnimation() providing the time interval between each frame
Call StopAnimation() to stop the animation

member.remarks: During animation the silhouettes, if enabled, are skipped.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D
member.summary: Utility class for performing Collision Detection 2D on Plane XY (for ICurve and Region types only).
member.remarks: The Regen() method needs to be called first for the interested entities (except for LinearPath).

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem
member.summary: The resulting sub-item of the tuple result. If the resulting collided entity is a leaf, then the name of the first block containing that entity will be saved into ParentName field and the trasformation field will be filled.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.Transformation
member.summary: The accumulated parent transformation of the collided entity.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.ParentName
member.summary: The block name of the first parent that contain that entity.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.Parents
member.summary: The parents stack to reach the entity.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionTupleItem.Entity
member.summary: The entity found intersecting in the resulting tuple.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType
member.summary: The accuracy type used during collision detection.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.OB
member.summary: Oriented Bounding check type- Computes a collision detection by using OrientedBoundingRect (for CollisionDetection2D) or OrientedBoundingBox (for CollisionDetection) intersection. The most approximated accuracy, the faster.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.SubdivisionTree
member.summary: Computes a collision detection by using intersection among QuadTree(for 2D) or Octree(for 3D) subdivision. More accurate than OB Accuracy, but slower during collision computation if the entities collection are transformed BlockReferences. Usefull for entities with complex but balanced tessellation.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.OBWithSubdivisionTree
member.summary: Computes a collision detection by using a combination of OBR/OBB and triangles/segments QuadTree/Octree subdivision intersections. Same accuracy of SubdivisionTree method, but faster during collision computation for deep Block\BlockReference gerarchy (it could be slower during computation of QuadTree\Octree and OBR\OBB data). Suggested for deep Block\BlockReferences hierarchy containing leaves entities with a complex/dense tessellation.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.collisionCheckType.Accurate
member.summary: Computes a collision detection by using Geometrical intersections. The most accurate but slower approach. Suggested if you need to find precise intersection for curved entities. Advised against animation and frequently translated entities.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionResult
member.summary: The resulting collision information after a Collision check between two colliding leaves entities.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.CollisionDetection2D.CollisionResult.CollidedEntities
member.summary: contains the information of both the colliding entities.

member.summary: When is called, it is filled with the list of the intersection volumes found between the tuple . When false it is filled only during checkMethod with the collision information found during the ordinary check.

member.summary: The function used by the marching cube algorithm to evaluate the 3D scalar field.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Triangulation.MarchingCubes
member.summary:
Utility class for creating a polygonal surface representation of an iso-surface of a 3D scalar field.
There are many applications for this type of technique, two very common ones are:
Reconstruction of a surface from medical volumetric datasets. For example MRI scans result in a 3d volume of samples at the vertices of a regular 3D mesh.
Creating a 3D contour of a mathematical scalar field. In this case the function is known everywhere but is sampled at the vertices of a regular 3D grid.

member.remarks: If true, the coincident vertices of the generated mesh are not welded and the is set to , else the vertices are welded and the is set to The generated mesh is created with the same value.

member.summary: The function used by the marching squares algorithm to evaluate the 2D scalar field.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Triangulation.MarchingSquares
member.summary: Utility class for creating a polygonal representation of an isocurve of a 2D scalar field.

example.code:
Public Sub MarchingSquares() Dim func As ScalarField2D = New ScalarField2D(AddressOf myScalarField)
Dim ms As MarchingSquares = new MarchingSquares(new Point2D(0, 0), 100, 1, 100, 1, func) ms.IsoLevel = 20 ms.DoWork() Dim isoCurv As Line() = ms.Result Assert.AreEqual(156, isoCurv.Length) End Sub Private Function myScalarField(ByVal x1 As Single, ByVal y1 As Single) As Single Dim pt As Point2D = New Point2D(x1, y1) Dim cen As Point2D = New Point2D(50, 50) Return Convert.ToSingle(cen.DistanceTo(pt)) End Function

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.RegenParams.Deviation
member.summary: Gets the maximum deviation. Determines the value between the analytical surface and its triangulation. The lower is the deviation value, the more accurate is the result.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.RegenParams.Angle
member.summary: Gets the maximum angular deflection in radians, ignored when zero.
member.remarks: This setting dictates the minimum number of facets around a smaller circle or cylinder regardless of the setting, and gives you added control over faces with very small radii. Lower values result in finer tessellations, while higher values give coarser tessellations.
