member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.rotationCenterType.ViewportCenter
member.summary: Viewport center. If the model is all inside the camera frustum, it rotates around its bounding box center. Else it rotates around the viewport center at a mean depth of the current visible scene.

member.name: F:devDept.Eyeshot.rotationCenterType.CursorLocation
member.summary: Current mouse cursor location. If the model is all inside the camera frustum, it rotates around its bounding box center. Else it rotates around the point under the mouse. If under the mouse there is no depth, the rotation happens around the viewport center at a mean depth of the current visible scene.

member.name: T:devDept.Eyeshot.Block
member.summary:
Block definition. Blocks have to be added to the master block array and inserted in the list using the entity.
A block in Eyeshot is a collection of entities that create an object, grouped together to make one selectable object. Selecting one particular entity will select all entities contained within the block. They can be moved, rotated, mirrored etc and will always be treated by Eyeshot as one whole object.
Blocks are an invaluable way of quickly arranging complex pieces of a design. Selecting the object is a breeze, it is no longer necessary to painstakingly select each individual entities. Blocks also make it easy to duplicate the same object throughout a drawing, and as Eyeshot recognizes that each copy of a block is identical to the previous, the memory and processing time required by Eyeshot is reduced.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Block.ConvexHull
member.summary: The convex hull of the surface.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Block.FullPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the forced full path for saving the file representing this block. Default value is null/Nothing.
member.remarks: This property is used when saving a file in a format supporting MultiFile feature, to force the destination output path for the single block (assembly or sub-assembly). By design, all files of the same assembly are stored in the same directory, but you can force a different path for a single assembly by using this property. It must include absolute path, filename and extension. When saving an assembly in Eyeshot MultiFile format, each block is automatically saved in the same directory specified for . If the block is not the root one, the name for the exported file is get from the block's itself. and the extension will be get according to the property. If the property is filled, it overrides the above automatism of course.

member.name: P:devDept.Eyeshot.Block.CustomData
member.summary: Gets or sets a custom object that will be stored to the Eyeshot Proprietary File Format.

remarks.para: You need to define the related for your custom data and you need to use a custom including definition for it.
If the type implements ICloneable it will be cloned when the Block is cloned.

member.seealso: The article about Eyeshot Proprietary File Format.

member.name: T:devDept.WorkUnit

summary.para: Base class for background working support. Overriding this class you can build a model or do your CPU intensive calculations on a separate thread keeping your application UI responsive.
Depending on the nature of the work you may need to override both the and methods or only the one and provide a to be notified when the work has completed.

member.summary: Creates a 2D texture from an image.

If true, the texture is repeated in the X direction
If true, the texture is repeated in the Y direction

member.name: T:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType
member.summary: The texture filtering function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area greater (minifying function) or smaller (magnifying function) than one texture element. There are six defined filtering functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.

member.name: F:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType.Nearest
member.summary: Returns the value of the texture element that is nearest (in Manhattan distance) to the center of the pixel being textured.

member.name: F:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType.Linear
member.summary: Returns the weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel being textured.

member.name: F:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType.NearestMipmapNearest
member.summary: Chooses the mipmap that most closely matches the size of the pixel being textured and uses the Nearest criterion (the texture element nearest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value.

member.name: F:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType.LinearMipmapNearest
member.summary: Chooses the mipmap that most closely matches the size of the pixel being textured and uses the Linear criterion (a weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value.

member.name: F:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType.NearestMipmapLinear
member.summary: Chooses the two mipmaps that most closely match the size of the pixel being textured and uses the Nearest criterion (the texture element nearest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value from each mipmap. The final texture value is a weighted average of those two values.

member.name: F:devDept.Graphics.textureFilteringFunctionType.LinearMipmapLinear
member.summary: Chooses the two mipmaps that most closely match the size of the pixel being textured and uses the Linear criterion (a weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value from each mipmap. The final texture value is a weighted average of those two values.

member.summary: Sets the stencil buffer entry to zero

member.summary: Increments the current stencil buffer value. Clamps to the maximum representable unsigned value.

member.summary: Decrements the current stencil buffer value. Clamps to 0.

member.remarks: The identifiers are self explanatory and determine: The depth test status and depth function (see the glDepthFunc() documentation), The stencil status, function, reference value and mask (see the glStencilFunc() documentation), The action to take when the stencil test fails, the depth test fails or both test pass (see the glStencilOp() documentation).
